00027 using namespace std;

00029 #define FALSE 0
00030 #define TRUE  1
00031 
00032 #define RESOLUTION 4096.0
00033 #define DEG_PER_REV 360.0
00034 
00035 // Default port. Assumes one QSB plugged in
00036 // and no other USB devices posing as serial
00037 // devices.
00038 #define SERIAL_PORT "/dev/rocker"
00039 
00040 
00041 
00042 // The response from a QSB has the general format:
00043 //
00044 //     Element: Response  Register  Data  TimeStamp  EOR
00045 //     Bytes  :     1         2       8       8       4
00046 //
00047 //
00048 // Response, Register and Data, are always present.
00049 //
00050 // The rest of the elements are determined by the EOR (15) register.
00051 // Each feature is enabled with a bit=1 or disabled with a bit=0.
00052 // The default value is: CR/LF = 0x03.
00053 //
00054 // BITS:   B3 B2 B1 B0
00055 //
00056 // B0 = Line Feed
00057 // B1 = Carriage Return
00058 // B2 = 4-byte Time Stamp appended to the response
00059 // B3 = Spaces between returned fields
00060 //
00061 // The timestamp is a 4-byte value but is appended to the
00062 // paket as an 8-byte hex string.
00063 //
00064 // If spaces are used, the resulting format is:
00065 //
00066 //   Response[space]Register[space]Data[space]TimeStampEOR
00067 //
00068 // Thus the last space is right after the data value. Any
00069 // trailing information (time stamp, etc.) is not separated
00070 // by spaces.
00071 //
00072 // The number below is size of the longest possible response
00073 // received from the QSB when all terminators are on and spaces
00074 // separate the elements. It also allows for the string termination.
00075 const int BUFFER_SIZE = 27;
00076 
00077 
00078 // The USB link between the QSB and the computer introduces
00079 // considerable lag. So, we need to wait a bit when sending
00080 // an instruction before we get the response. The value of
00081 // 5 ms is empirical and may need adjustment on other systems.
00082 const int FIVE_MILLISECONDS = 5000;
00083 
00084 
00085 // How many times we will try a non-blocking read of the
00086 // device before we call it a failed operation.
00087 const int MAX_READ_TRIES = 20;
00088 
00089 
00090 
00091 // Rather than getting into complications reading the
00092 // keyboard for input, we will just trap Ctrl+C and
00093 // notify the app when the user is done.
00094 int CloseRequested = FALSE;
00095 
00096 
00097 
00098 void printQsbError(char* errorMessage)
00099 {
00100        ROS_ERROR("%s: %d - %s", errorMessage, errno, strerror(errno));
00101        exit(-1);
00102 }
00103 
00104 
00105 
00106 
00107 // The QSB presents itself to the system as a vanilla
00108 // UART and we can talk to it using the standard
00109 // POSIX IO functions.
00110 //
00111 // In the two utilitarian functions below, 'qsb' is
00112 // a standard UNIX file handle pointing to the serial
00113 // port where the devices is hosted.
00114 
00115 
00116 void sendQsbInstruction(int qsb, char* command)
00117 {
00118     // Create a padded instruction string that includes
00119     // CR+LF. The QSB will be happy with just CR or LF too.
00120     char* qsbCommand = (char *)malloc(strlen(command) + 3);
00121     sprintf(qsbCommand, "%s\r\n", command);
00122 
00123     int ioResult = write(qsb, qsbCommand, strlen(qsbCommand));
00124     free(qsbCommand);
00125 
00126     if (ioResult < 0)
00127     {
00128         printQsbError("Error writing to QSB device");
00129     }
00130 }
00131 
00132 
00133 void readQsbResponse(int qsb, char* response, int responseSize)
00134 {
00135     int i = 0;
00136     int ioResult;
00137     do
00138     {
00139         ioResult = read(qsb, response, responseSize);
00140         // This delay is to give some time to the device to
00141         // pipe the information to the serial port.
00142         usleep(FIVE_MILLISECONDS);
00143         i++;
00144     } while (ioResult < 0 && errno == EAGAIN && i < MAX_READ_TRIES);
00145 
00146     if (i == MAX_READ_TRIES)
00147     {
00148         printQsbError("Error reading from QSB device");
00149     }
00150 
00151     // Remove the trailing CR+LF if any, and trim to proper size.
00152     int end = strcspn(response, "\r\n");
00153     response[end] = '\0';
00154 
00155     if (ioResult < responseSize)
00156     {
00157         response[ioResult] = '\0';
00158     }
00159 }
00160 
00161 
00162 // Every instruction sent to the QSB is acknowledged
00163 // with a corresponding response string. We then send
00164 // the instruction and retrieve the response as a
00165 // single command transaction.
00166 void qsbCommand(int qsb, char* command, char* response, int responseSize)
00167 {
00168     sendQsbInstruction(qsb, command);
00169     readQsbResponse(qsb, response, responseSize);
00170 }
00171 
00172 
00173 
00174 void ctrlCHandler(int signal)
00175 {
00176     CloseRequested = TRUE;
00177 }
00178 
00179 
00180 // *************************************************
00181 //
00182 //  General flow of operation:
00183 //   1. Open the port and configure it.
00184 //      The QSB UART wants 230.4K Baud, 8-n-1
00185 //   2. Set up the QSB to read an encoder.
00186 //   3. Loop polling and printing the current
00187 //      encoder count.
00188 //   4. Upon close request, close the port and
00189 //      exit.
00190 //
00191 // *************************************************
00192 
00193 int main (int argc, char *argv[])
00194 {
00195         double offset=0;
00196         double rate=0;
00197     // Register the Ctrl-C handler.
00198     signal(SIGINT, ctrlCHandler);
00199 
00200     // Initialize ROS node and publisher
00201     ros::init(argc, argv, "rocker_position");
00202 
00203     ros::NodeHandle n;
00204 
00205     std::string port;
00206     // Open the port.  If a port is passed as argument use that otherwise use the default one /dev/ttyUSB0
00207     int qsb;
00208         port = SERIAL_PORT;
00209         ros::param::get("~Offset",offset);
00210     ros::param::get("~Port",port);
00211     ros::param::get("~Rate",rate);
00212     qsb = open(port.c_str(), O_RDWR | O_NOCTTY | O_NONBLOCK);
00213 
00214     for( int i=0; i<50;i++){
00215         qsb = open(port.c_str(), O_RDWR | O_NOCTTY | O_NONBLOCK);
00216         if(qsb>=0) break;
00217         sleep(10);
00218     }
00219     if (qsb < 0)
00220     {
00221         printQsbError("Error opening QSB device");
00222     }
00223         
00224 
00225     // Configure it.
00226     struct termios qsbConfiguration;
00227     tcgetattr(qsb, &qsbConfiguration);
00228 
00229     qsbConfiguration.c_cflag = B230400 | CS8;
00230     cfsetospeed(&qsbConfiguration, B230400);
00231     tcflush(qsb, TCIFLUSH);
00232     tcsetattr(qsb, TCSANOW, &qsbConfiguration);
00233 
00234 
00235 
00236     // Below is the basic communications protocol with
00237     // the QSB. The commands were composed using the
00238     // QSB command list available for download at the
00239     // US Digital site.
00240 
00241 
00242     char* command;
00243     char response[BUFFER_SIZE];
00244 
00245 
00246     // Read and print product information.
00247     // Register: VERSION (0x14)
00248     qsbCommand(qsb, "R14", response, BUFFER_SIZE);
00249    // printf("Product info: %s\n", response);
00250 
00251     // Set encoder in PWM mode.
00252     // Register: MODE (0x00)
00253     qsbCommand(qsb, "W0001", response, BUFFER_SIZE);
00254     //printf("Mode response: %s\n", response);
00255 
00256     // Read encoder resolution
00257     // Register: MODE (0x00)
00258     qsbCommand(qsb, "R00", response, BUFFER_SIZE);
00259 
00260     char * pch;
00261     unsigned long resolution;
00262     pch = strtok(response, " ");
00263     pch = strtok(NULL, " ");
00264     pch = strtok(NULL, " ");
00265     resolution = strtoul (pch, NULL, 16);
00266     if(resolution != 0){
00267         resolution = 12;
00268     } else resolution = 10;
00269 
00270     //cout << "Encoder resolution: " << resolution << "-bit" << endl;
00271 
00272    // puts("\nUse Ctrl+C to exit.\n\n");
00273 
00274 
00275 
00276     ros::Publisher rocker_position_pub = n.advertise<std_msgs::Float32>
00277                 ("Rocker_Position", 1);
00278 
00279     ros::Rate loop_rate(rate);
00280 
00281 
00282     while (CloseRequested == FALSE && ros::ok())
00283     {
00284         unsigned long ticks;
00285         float degrees;
00286         std_msgs::Float32 msg;
00287                 
00288         // Read current count.
00289         // Register: READ ENCODER (0x0E)
00290         qsbCommand(qsb, "R0E", response, BUFFER_SIZE);
00291 
00292        // printf("Current count: %s\r", response);
00293 
00294         pch = strtok(response, " ");
00295         pch = strtok(NULL, " ");
00296         pch = strtok(NULL, " ");
00297         ticks = strtoul (pch, NULL, 16);
00298         degrees = DEG_PER_REV * ((float) ticks / RESOLUTION)-(float)offset;
00299 
00300         // Publish to ROS
00301         msg.data = degrees;
00302         rocker_position_pub.publish(msg);
00303         ros::spinOnce();
00304         loop_rate.sleep();
00305     }
00306 
00307     close(qsb);
00308     puts("\n");
00309     return(0);
00310 }
